title: Medicare for Autism Services
shortDescription: Federal health insurance for adults with disabilities that covers medical care, therapy evaluations, and some autism-related services.
description: Medicare is federal health insurance primarily for people 65 and older, but also covers adults under 65 with certain disabilities, including autism. Medicare has different parts covering different services. While it covers medical care, diagnostic evaluations, and some therapies, coverage for intensive behavioral interventions like ABA therapy is limited. Many adults with autism qualify for Medicare after receiving Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) for 24 months.
whoQualifies: Adults under 65 who have received SSDI for 24 months
Adults with End-Stage Renal Disease or ALS
Must be a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident for 5+ years
whatIsCovered: Doctor visits and autism-related medical care
Outpatient mental health therapy and counseling
Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy (when medically necessary)
whatIsNotCovered: Most ABA therapy (limited coverage in some states)
Personal care assistance for daily living

medicareParts.part_a: Hospital Insurance - Covers inpatient hospital stays, skilled nursing, hospice
medicareParts.part_b: Medical Insurance - Covers doctor visits, outpatient care, therapies, mental health
medicareParts.part_c: Medicare Advantage - Private insurance alternative that includes A & B, often with extras
medicareParts.part_d: Prescription Drug Coverage - Helps pay for medications

typicalCosts.copays: 20% coinsurance for Part B services after deductible

floridaSpecificInfo: Florida has many Medicare Advantage plans with autism-friendly benefits
Some Medicare Advantage plans in Florida offer limited ABA therapy coverage
Florida residents can get help choosing plans through SHINE (Serving Health Insurance Needs of Elders)
Medicaid may supplement Medicare for low-income individuals (dual eligible)

commonQuestions.question: Does Medicare cover ABA therapy for adults with autism?
commonQuestions.answer: Traditional Medicare provides very limited ABA coverage. Some Medicare Advantage plans may offer limited coverage. Check specific plan details.

commonQuestions.question: How do I qualify for Medicare if I am under 65 with autism?
commonQuestions.answer: You must receive Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) for 24 months. Apply for SSDI first, then Medicare enrollment happens automatically.

commonQuestions.question: Should I choose Original Medicare or Medicare Advantage?
commonQuestions.answer: Compare both. Medicare Advantage may offer extra benefits like dental, vision, and limited behavioral health services, but has network restrictions.

commonQuestions.question: Can I have both Medicare and Medicaid?
commonQuestions.answer: Yes! Many people with disabilities are 'dual eligible.' Medicaid can help pay Medicare premiums and cover services Medicare does not.
